resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:757943814</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-OHRRH</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Mackay, Kathleen, 1948-</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Kathleen Mackay Research Papers (Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum. Library and Archives)</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Kathleen Mackay Research Papers 1967-2007.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The Kathleen Mackay Research Papers span the years of 1967 to 2007, with the bulk of the collection dating between 2005 and 2007. The collection consists primarily of the interviews done as research for Mackay's 2007 book, Bob Dylan: Intimate Insights from Friends and Fellow Musicians. This collection also includes drafts of the aforementioned book from 2006, interviews on audio cassette, and a copy of the Monterey International Pop Festival's annual program from 1967. Artists of note in the collection are Rosanne Cash, Liam Clancy, Kris Kristofferson, Ronnie Hawkins, and Maria Muldaur among others. Mackay's collection provides a behind-the-scenes look at rock music journalism and biography, as well as the research, primary source material, and editing required by the writing process. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum - Library and Archives</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Kathleen Mackay Research Papers 1967-2007.
resource.abstract: The Kathleen Mackay Research Papers span the years of 1967 to 2007, with the bulk of the collection dating between 2005 and 2007. The collection consists primarily of the interviews done as research for Mackay's 2007 book, Bob Dylan: Intimate Insights from Friends and Fellow Musicians. This collection also includes drafts of the aforementioned book from 2006, interviews on audio cassette, and a copy of the Monterey International Pop Festival's annual program from 1967. Artists of note in the collection are Rosanne Cash, Liam Clancy, Kris Kristofferson, Ronnie Hawkins, and Maria Muldaur among others. Mackay's collection provides a behind-the-scenes look at rock music journalism and biography, as well as the research, primary source material, and editing required by the writing process.

<objectXMLWrap>
               <did xmlns="urn:isbn:1-931666-22-9">
                  <langmaterial>
                     <language>English</language>

                  <repository>
                     <corpname>University of Rhode Island Library, Special Collections and University Archives</corpname>
                     <address>
                        <addressline>15 Lippitt Road</addressline>
                        <addressline>Kingston, RI 02881-2011</addressline>
                        <addressline>Tel: 401-874-4632</addressline>
                        <addressline>
                           <extptr/>E-mail: archives@etal.uri.edu</addressline>
                        <addressline>
                           <extptr/>Website: http://www.uri.edu/library/special_collections/</addressline>
                     </address>
                  </repository>
                  <origination>
                     <famname>Bonoff family</famname>
                  </origination>
                  <unittitle>Bonoff Family Papers</unittitle>
                  <unitdate>1899-2007</unitdate>
                  <unittitle>Bonoff family papers</unittitle>
                  <physdesc>
                     <extent>123 linear feet</extent>
                     <extent>118 box(es)</extent>
                  </physdesc>
                  <abstract>The collection consists of the records of the Bonoff family. The Bonoffs operated home demonstration shows and ran several theatres in Phoenix, AZ, and in New England from the 1940s to the late 1990s. The majority of the records deal with the operation of the Warwick Musical Theatre in Warwick, R.I.</abstract>
                  <unitid>Mss. Gr. 216</unitid>
               </did>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Bonoff Family Papers Bonoff family papers 1899-2007
resource.abstract: The collection consists of the records of the Bonoff family. The Bonoffs operated home demonstration shows and ran several theatres in Phoenix, AZ, and in New England from the 1940s to the late 1990s. The majority of the records deal with the operation of the Warwick Musical Theatre in Warwick, R.I.

resource.title: Southern Folklife Collection Artist Name File, 1940-2005
resource.abstract: The materials in this collection were compiled from various sources by Southern Folklife Collection staff, with the goal of creating a reference resource to aid in research. Artist name files contain correspondence, booklets, obituaries, press releases, discographies, promotional materials, and other items relating to many of the artists whose work is relevant to the Southern Folklife Collection as a whole.
resource.displayEntry: Southern Folklife Collection Artist Name File, 1940-2005

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:777597151</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-OHRRH</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Moyssiadis, James D.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Zakarin, Marc,</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Zakarin, Debra,</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Churchmouse / Moyssi Programs (Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum. Library and Archives)</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Churchmouse/Moyssi Programs , 1974-1984, undated.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The Churchmouse / Moyssi Programs span the years 1974 and 1978 to 1984 and consists of black-and-white programs. The programs feature original art by James D. Moyssiadis (aka, Moyssi). They were predominately produced for national touring acts that appeared at the Capitol Theatre in Passaic, N.J., but also represent several other venues in New York and New Jersey in association with the "John Scher Presents" series. They were distributed to audiences free of charge, and also contain biographical information on the performers, photographs, and local advertisements. The Churchmouse / Moyssi Programs provide rich insight to rock fan culture of the late-1970s and early 1980s, and showcase the rock music scene on the east coast. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum - Library and Archives</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Churchmouse/Moyssi Programs , 1974-1984, undated.
resource.abstract: The Churchmouse / Moyssi Programs span the years 1974 and 1978 to 1984 and consists of black-and-white programs. The programs feature original art by James D. Moyssiadis (aka, Moyssi). They were predominately produced for national touring acts that appeared at the Capitol Theatre in Passaic, N.J., but also represent several other venues in New York and New Jersey in association with the "John Scher Presents" series. They were distributed to audiences free of charge, and also contain biographical information on the performers, photographs, and local advertisements. The Churchmouse / Moyssi Programs provide rich insight to rock fan culture of the late-1970s and early 1980s, and showcase the rock music scene on the east coast.

resource.source:
Harvard Theatre Collection, Houghton Library, Harvard College Library, Harvard University Harvard Depository

This collection is shelved offsite at the Harvard Depository. See access restrictions below for additional information.

 MS Thr 675 Beal, George Brinton. George Brinton Beal papers, circus collection, and other theatrical collections, 1862-1969. 31 boxes (12 linear ft.) Collection materials are primarily in English, with a few in German, Danish, and French. Personal papers of and materials collected by American critic, editor, lecturer, and writer George Brinton Beal. Especially concerns the circus, rodeo, theater, and other forms of popular entertainment.
resource.title: George Brinton Beal papers, circus collection, and other theatricalcollections, 1862-1969.
resource.abstract: Personal papers of and materials collected by American critic, editor,lecturer, and writer George Brinton Beal. Especially concerns the circus, rodeo,theater, and other forms of popular entertainment.
resource.displayEntry: George Brinton Beal papers, circus collection, and other theatrical collections, 1862-1969.

nameEntries.original: Harvard Theatre Collection, Houghton Library, Harvard College Library, Harvard University.

resourceRelations.content: George Brinton Beal papers, circus collection, and other theatrical collections, 1862-1969.
